questions.question_text: the css property responsible for setting an element’s typeface is...
questions.explanation: font-face and type-face don’t exist. For those who chose the font property, that property exists and does more than just select the typeface. See page 273 in HTML & CSS for details.

questions.question_text: a common unit of measure for type on the web is not...
questions.explanation: See page 274 in HTML & CSS for details.

questions.question_text: kerning is to letter-spacing as leading is to _______.
questions.explanation: There is only one valid CSS property among the mix, line-height. Yes, it’s weird there’s no property named leading, but that’s the way the CSS cookie crumbles. Also note that there’s no concept of “space after” a paragraph; this is accomplished by adding bottom margin to paragraph elements. See page 283 in HTML & CSS for details.

questions.question_text: true or false: :first-line is an example of a pseudo-class.
questions.explanation:
It’s an example of a pseudo-element. A pseudo-element acts like an extra element is in the code. A pseudo-class, on the other hand, selects elements that are in a specific state. Unfortunately, both are written with a single preceding colon, even though they are different. In newer versions of the CSS specification, pseudo-elements are written with two preceding colons, as in ::first-line. (Here’s a good summary of the one- vs. two-colon situation.) View the differences between pseudo-elements and pseudo-classes here. See also page 289 in HTML & CSS.

My favorite pseudo-elements are ::before and ::after, especially when combined with the content property.

questions.question_text: how many link states can be styled?
questions.explanation: Dude, you can style up to five states: :link (an unvisited link), :visited (a visited link), :hover (mousing over), :active (mouse clicking), and :focus (keyboard focus). See pages 290–291 in HTML & CSS for details.

questions.question_text: The following are all valid attribute selectors except...
questions.explanation: The first option is called an equality selector. The second option is called a space selector. The third option is called a prefix selector. See page 292 in HTML & CSS for what they do.

questions.question_text: the following css properties can have transitions except...
questions.explanation: Virtually all properties whose values are numeric can be animated (a handy time to remember that colors can be represented numerically). The values for the display property are not numeric, therefore it cannot be transitioned.

questions.question_text: according to dan cederholm, animation on the web should be used...
questions.explanation: “Like all shiny new tools, it’s important to use transitions appropriately. One can easily go overboard adding transitions to everything on the page, resulting in some sort of annoying, pulsating monster. It’s key to decide where transitions rightfully enrich the user experience and when they are just extraneous noise.” –Dan Cederholm, CSS3 for Web Designers, page 26

questions.question_text:
the css snippet below...
p {
color: brown;
transition: color .3s ease ;
}
...will do what when someone hovers over a hypothetical paragraph element?

answers.answer_text: turn the text brown over the course of 3 seconds
turn the text brown over the course of 300 milliseconds
we don’t know what it will do

questions.explanation:
In order for something to happen, we would need to define a second rule for the hover state: p:hover { ... }. We would have to add a declaration with the color property to change the color, which it would do over the course of 300 milliseconds per the first rule.

Note that transitions are assigned to the mouse-off state rule, not the hover state rule.

questions.question_text: all of the following capabilities were introduced in CSS3 except...
questions.explanation: CSS3 was crammed with so much goodness that the makers decided to wait until CSS4 to include the ability to travel through time (DeLorean style, of course).
